speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to start by asking you a few questions. Can you tell me when these episodes of unresponsiveness first started, and how often they occur?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about a month ago. I think they happen a few times a week, but I'm not really sure, my mom keeps track of them for me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe what you experience during these episodes? Do you feel any pain or discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes I get this weird feeling in my mouth, like someone put mud in it. And then my face feels weird too, like I'm trying to make a funny face but I don't know why.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your descriptions. I'd like to know more about the nature of the facial grimacing you experience during these episodes. Is it a constant grimace or does it change expression?

speaker: Patient
text: My face gets all scrunched up and then it changes to a really weird shape, like my mouth is open really wide and my eyebrows are all bunched up. Sometimes my eyes get all squinty too.

speaker: Doctor
text: How long have you been experiencing these episodes, and have you noticed any triggers or specific situations that might set them off?

speaker: Patient
text: They started about a month ago. I don't think anything triggers them, but sometimes I feel really tired or confused afterwards.

speaker: Doctor
text: The facial grimacing - can you tell me if it's more of a spasmodic movement or does it seem to be related to your jaw or mouth?

speaker: Patient
text: My jaw feels like it's moving on its own, like it's doing something it shouldn't be doing. It's not like I'm trying to chew or anything, it's just... weird.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned earlier that a doctor with similar symptoms was later diagnosed with cancer, but I'd like to know if you've noticed any unusual growths or lumps on or around your face, particularly around the area where you experience the facial grimacing?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. My mom says I'm a little pale lately, but I don't know if that's because of these episodes or not.

speaker: Doctor
text: The episodes started about 2 months ago, and they occur about 3-4 times a week. Can you tell me if you've experienced any difficulty with speaking or swallowing during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I can talk very well during those episodes. Sometimes I try to say something, but my mouth feels all weird and it comes out all wrong.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned episodes occur about 3-4 times a week, can you tell me if there's any pattern to when these episodes happen, such as during the day or at night?

speaker: Patient
text: They happen at different times, but sometimes they happen when I'm sitting in class or when I'm eating dinner. My mom said it's usually when I'm doing something quiet.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any numbness or tingling sensations in your face, arms, or legs during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes my face feels numb, like my lips and tongue are sleeping. But it's not just my face, it's like my whole body feels a little bit weird and sleepy.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you noticed any changes in your vision or hearing during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've noticed anything different with my vision or hearing during those episodes. Sometimes I feel like I'm staring at something, but I don't know what it is or where it is.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms. Can you tell me if you've experienced any weight loss or changes in appetite since these episodes started?

speaker: Patient
text: I think I've lost a little bit of weight since these episodes started, but my mom says I'm still eating a lot. Sometimes I feel really hungry after the episodes, though.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms, and I'd like to ask, have you experienced any difficulty with walking or balance during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really feel like I'm walking right during those episodes. It's like my legs are moving, but I'm not really in control of them.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the facial grimacing you experience during these episodes in more detail? Is it more of a twitching or a tightening of the muscles?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like my face is getting all stiff and my muscles are contracting, but it's hard to explain. It's like my face is trying to do something, but I don't know what it wants to do.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your detailed description of the facial grimacing. Now, I'd like to know if you've experienced any fever or chills before or after these episodes.

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, I just feel really tired and confused afterwards. Sometimes my mom gives me a thermometer to check if I have a fever, but it's always normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if these episodes ever seem to be triggered by eating or drinking something, or if you experience any difficulty swallowing food or liquids during an episode?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, sometimes I get this weird feeling in my mouth right before it happens, like I said earlier, it's like someone put mud in it. And sometimes it feels like my tongue is getting all tangled up.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that these episodes occur about 3-4 times a week, and you haven't noticed any specific pattern to when they happen. Can you tell me if the duration of each episode is relatively short, or do they last for several minutes or even hours?

speaker: Patient
text: They're usually pretty short, but it feels like forever when I'm going through it. They last around 3-4 minutes, I think. Sometimes it feels like time is standing still and I'm stuck in this weird place.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in your tongue during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, sometimes my tongue feels numb and tingly, like it's asleep or something. And sometimes it feels like it's getting all tangled up in my mouth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Now that I've taken note of your symptoms, I'd like to ask, have you experienced any muscle weakness in your face, arms, or legs during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes my arms feel really weak during those episodes, like I'm trying to lift something but I don't have the strength to do it. And my legs feel all wobbly too.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned earlier that the episodes started about 2 months ago, and you experience them about 3-4 times a week. Have you noticed any increase in these episodes over time, or have they remained relatively consistent?

speaker: Patient
text: They seem to be happening more often lately. I'm not really sure, but it feels like they're getting closer together. Sometimes I feel like I'm waiting for the next one to happen.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of your symptoms and I must say, I'm concerned about the possibility of a neurological condition. Before I make a diagnosis, I'd like to request some test results to help me better understand what's going on.

REQUEST TEST: EEG

Also, I'd like to examine your face and jaw more closely to see if I can find any abnormalities. Can you please open your mouth and show me your teeth?
